Award.AwardTitle: A high throughput platform for the selective generation of neurons from stem cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Human induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) can grow indefinitely in culture and be specified to almost any cell type found in the human body. As such, they represent an attractive avenue for tissue engineering and cell replacement therapy. However, it remains difficult to convert iPSCs into sspecific cell types, which hinders their applications. This project uses a unique engineered device to simultaneously examine the effects of many different chemical cues on iPSC specification. The model system to be studied involves the generation of a subtype of neurons whose loss causes Parkinson's Disease (PD). Thus, the immediate outcomes of this project will have positive impacts on PD patients, and potential long-term implications for using iPSCs to replace other diseased tissues. The project will also support research experiences for undergraduates and for high school students through an existing outreach program with the Nashville public school system.

Human induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) have the potential to revolutionize personalized medicine by serving as an unlimited source of patient-derived material for disease modeling, drug screening, and tissue engineering. A key challenge remaining is the reproducible differentiation of individual iPSC lines to homogeneous populations of the desired cell type. A majority of iPSC differentiation procedures yield heterogeneous cell mixtures, and differentiation conditions identified for one iPSC line often do not translate to other lines. Whereas in vivo development relies on diverse spatiotemporal cues, where subtle differences in growth factor concentrations can alter lineage trajectories, standard iPSC differentiation procedures utilize static cultures with infrequent media changes that lack continuous control over soluble protein and small molecule concentrations. As such, the objective of this proposal is utilize a unique microformulator platform, which permits independent media delivery to each well of a standard 96-well plate, for iPSC differentiations. The proposal's specific aims will be focused on producing A9 midbrain dopaminergic (DA) neurons, which are the cell type lost in Parkinson's Disease (PD). DA neurons have been previously differentiated from iPSCs but with heterogeneous identity and line-to-line variability. Thus, the utility and significance of the microformulator will be demonstrated by: 1) iterative screening of differentiation conditions that yield highly pure midbrain DA progenitors from a single iPSC line; 2) iterative screening of differentiation conditions that favor high purity A9 midbrain DA neurons over other DA subtypes; and 3) demonstration of rapid optimization of differentiation conditions to multiple iPSC lines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project extended the concept for an automated, microfluidic control technology (Figure 1) developed by researchers at Vanderbilt University for pharmaceutical-industry studies of anti-cancer drugs to the totally different problem of optimizing the differentiation of induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) into particular cell types as needed for biological research. The intellectual merit of this project is centered on the lack of any automated platforms to direct, optimize, and streamline iPSC differentiation. With the exception of a not yet completed final demonstration of iPSC differentiation to a subtype of midbrain dopaminergic neurons, the objectives of the proposal were completed after extensive troubleshooting. First, to overcome the necessity of a month-long calibration process for the fluidics, a fully automated gravimetric pump and valve process was developed to perform calibrations in 30 hours. During this process, aspects of the design and production of microfluidic pumps and valves were identified for improvement, for example where tolerances needed to be tightened and assembly and alignment simplified. As part of a larger effort to improve the microcontroller systems used to operate the pumps and valves, we identified multiple, subtle sources of noise in cabling and a commercial stepper motor that led to a new design and prototyped controller specifically for this machine. We further addressed problems in systems sterilization through hardware and protocol design. Last, we identified how to solve long-standing problems in alignment and compression of the microfluidic pumps and valves, leading to a new actuation mechanism that is vastly easier to assemble, align, compress, and replace. These designs have all been ported into the final MicroFormulator system (Figure 2).

Throughout this process, we contributed significantly to the education of four high school, two undergraduate, and two graduate students working on projects related to this grant. We also advanced the professional training of several staff engineers. 

The potential impact of this project is extremely broad. It has introduced novel instruments and procedures required for long-term, automated, individualized cell culture in multi-well plates, with complete control of formulation for each well's culture media. The ability to control the time course of media composition in each well will enable parallel exploration of a breadth of phenomena in cellular, molecular, and systems biology, toxicology, and pharmacology. Further, this project has laid the foundation for the coupling of current microfluidic hardware and software to massively parallel, continuous-flow microchemostats, high throughput mass spectrometry metabolomics and proteomics, and artificial intellegence/machine learning to generate computational models of underlying biology. Hence, future projects based on efforts from this grant will be able to advance understanding and control over many biological systems.
